docs.snippet: The United States Postal Service has announced that the new 18-cent coil stamp will feature a portrait of George Washington with the Washington Monument in the background. The first day of issue is Nov. 6 in Washington, D.C. Stamps will go on sale...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Postal Service has announced that the new 18-cent coil stamp will feature a portrait of George Washington with the Washington Monument in the background. The first day of issue is Nov. 6 in Washington, D.C. Stamps will go on sale across the country Nov. 7. The 18-cent denomination meets the basic presort rate for first-class letter mail. The design was unveiled Feb. 16 in Richmond, Va. At that time the stamp was expected to be released in July, but the heavy schedule of new issues this year resulted in its postponement. The George Washington portrait depicted is primarily based on a Gilbert Stuart painting. Since the Washington Monument was dedicated 100 years ago, its inclusion on this stamp is an appropriate gesture. This is the first stamp designed by Thomas Szumowski of Waltham, Mass.

docs.snippet: South America explodes into spring in October, and Buenos Aires -above all, a walker's city - is one of the best cities in which to savor the approach of the Southern Hemisphere's summer. The Argentine capital is full of parks, cafes, streets of...
docs.lead_paragraph: South America explodes into spring in October, and Buenos Aires -above all, a walker's city - is one of the best cities in which to savor the approach of the Southern Hemisphere's summer. The Argentine capital is full of parks, cafes, streets of luxurious shopping, and a panoply of well-dressed Argentines who love nothing better than showing off themselves and their city to foreigners. It is also the time of year when Argentines escape on the weekends to their country places, clubs and beaches. The visitor might want to follow to retreats such as Bariloche, a mountain resort where spring means the skiers depart and the trout fishermen arrive, or, just across the River Plate, to the beach resort of Punta del Este in Uruguay.

byline.original: By Lydia Chavez; LYDIA CHAVEZ is chief of the Buenos Aires bureau of The Times

docs.snippet: If the United Nations, as its critics charge, is a Tower of Babel, then the teams of interpreters are the tour guides, the indispensable link helping diplomats from 159 nations to speak a common language.   On Monday, at a luncheon sponsored by Nancy...
docs.lead_paragraph: If the United Nations, as its critics charge, is a Tower of Babel, then the teams of interpreters are the tour guides, the indispensable link helping diplomats from 159 nations to speak a common language. On Monday, at a luncheon sponsored by Nancy Reagan, they hovered behind the wives of world leaders. In the darkened booths above the General Assembly, they interpreted a speech delivered in French by the President of Senegal, Abdou Diouf. And in basement conference rooms, they dealt with the details of disarmament and development.

headline.main: U.N.'S GIFT TO TONGUES: A CORPS OF INTERPRETERS

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The Reagan Administration is hoping that a consensus in favor of its recent initiative to ease the global debt crisis will emerge here Monday at a closed-door meeting of commercial banks holding 85 percent of the third world's debt.   But opposition...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration is hoping that a consensus in favor of its recent initiative to ease the global debt crisis will emerge here Monday at a closed-door meeting of commercial banks holding 85 percent of the third world's debt. But opposition to the plan, which calls on the banks to lend an additional $20 billion over three years to debtors that streamline their economies, could delay, or even prevent, a public endorsement, which the United States seeks. Some European bankers say they doubt the wisdom of calling on banks to increase their holdings of shaky loans. They say that the governments of industrialized countries should be playing a larger role by giving more credits, and by guaranteeing more of any new commercial bank loans.

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: In the recent history of Argentina's dictatorship so many people were kidnapped and tortured by right-wing death squads and then vanished without trace that a grisly noun came into common use: ''Los Desaparecidos'' - the disappeared ones. Their...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the recent history of Argentina's dictatorship so many people were kidnapped and tortured by right-wing death squads and then vanished without trace that a grisly noun came into common use: ''Los Desaparecidos'' - the disappeared ones. Their children, treated as war booty, were often given to government officials or sympathizers who were childless. ''The Official Story,'' a prize-winning Argentine film that is called ''Los Desaparecidos'' in Spanish, examines the social and psychological trauma that is the legacy of such practices even today, after democracy has come. The film, opening Friday at the Paris Theater, tells the story of an upper-middle-class mother who begins to suspect that her beloved daughter, whom she adopted as an infant five years before, may have belonged to one of the mothers or grandmothers whose agonized faces she sees begging for the return of their lost children outside the presidential offices at the Plaza de Mayor in Buenos Aires. It is also the story of the consequences of refusing to believe in unpalatable truths - of blindness caused by the unwillingness to see.

docs.snippet: Strongly influenced by the activist bishops of Brazil, Latin America's Roman Catholic Church is for the first time giving priority to establishing a permanent interchange of ideas with the region's Jewish groups.   At a conference of Catholic and...
docs.lead_paragraph: Strongly influenced by the activist bishops of Brazil, Latin America's Roman Catholic Church is for the first time giving priority to establishing a permanent interchange of ideas with the region's Jewish groups. At a conference of Catholic and Jewish leaders here this week, an impressive turnout of Catholic prelates was seen as a mark of the importance these clergymen give to eliminating the legacy in Latin America of distrust toward Judaism and ignorance about it. The prelates included Paulo Evaristo Cardinal Arns of Sao Paulo, Jean-Marie Cardinal Lustiger of Paris, the Presidents of the Latin American and the Brazilian Conferences of Bishops, the Secretary of the Holy See's Commission for Relations with Jews and seven other Brazilian prelates.

headline.main: THE CHURCH IN LATIN AMERICA SEEKS INTERCHANGE WITH JEWS

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Emir Rodriguez Monegal, director of graduate studies in Spanish and Portuguese at Yale University, died Thursday at the university's Health Services infirmary in New Haven. He was 64 years old and lived in New Haven.
docs.lead_paragraph: Emir Rodriguez Monegal, director of graduate studies in Spanish and Portuguese at Yale University, died Thursday at the university's Health Services infirmary in New Haven. He was 64 years old and lived in New Haven.

docs.snippet: ON Sept. 28, 15 well-appointed ocean-racing yachts ranging in size from 50 to 82 feet set sail from Portsmouth, England, for the first leg of the Whitbread Round-the-World Race. Cape Town was 7,000 miles away, and in this race, dubbed the ''sailor's...
docs.lead_paragraph: ON Sept. 28, 15 well-appointed ocean-racing yachts ranging in size from 50 to 82 feet set sail from Portsmouth, England, for the first leg of the Whitbread Round-the-World Race. Cape Town was 7,000 miles away, and in this race, dubbed the ''sailor's Everest,'' it was just the beginning. During the next seven months, through fair weather and foul, this fleet manned by adventurers from 10 nations will call at Auckland, New Zealand, and Punta del Este, Uruguay, before returning to England sometime next May. By then, they will have logged more than 27,000 miles. By virtue of the time involved and the businesslike-manner of the crews and sponsors, this event - unlike the kindlier forms of yachting that are considered to be a game in life - becomes your whole life. As a lifer indeed, this is my third Whitbread Race. If the act of skippering the pop star Simon Le Bon's yacht, Drum, didn't come with enough inherent notoriety, then our untimely capsizing off the British coast during last summer's Fastnet Race certainly did. All 24 crewmen were rescued. But with the keel falling off the boat as it did, it was an incident that rocked the marine industry.

headline.main: CHESS MATCH AT SEA, 7,000 MILES OF MOVES

byline.original: By SKIP NOVAK; Skip Novak of Chicago is skipper of the British maxiyacht Drum in the Whitbread Round-the-World Race. The fleet is scheduled to set out Dec. 4 for Auckland, New Zealand, on the second leg of the race

docs.snippet: As the weather turns warm in South America, whatever the economic climate, one idea takes hold of most Argentines -it's time for the annual vacation.   This nation's summer season, and how it is spent, says much about the country's union rights,...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the weather turns warm in South America, whatever the economic climate, one idea takes hold of most Argentines -it's time for the annual vacation. This nation's summer season, and how it is spent, says much about the country's union rights, class system and convivial spirit. In Argentina it is not only the rich who travel. The powerful unions made the summer vacation an egalitarian frolic in the 1940's by building huge seaside hotels for their members. Since then the Argentine summer season has become sacrosanct.

headline.main: THE LURE (AND THE LORE) OF ARGENTINA'S SUMMER

byline.original: By LYDIA CHAVEZ, Special to the New York Times
